summary: 1/3 When Arya tells Jon, "Try telling that to Sansa," his starts taking rapid breaths. All season, he's seen Dany make...
question: 1/3 When Arya tells Jon, "Try telling that to Sansa," his starts taking rapid breaths. All season, he's seen Dany make passive-aggressive comments about Sansa and he's tried not to react. But here, just Arya mentioning Sansa has him scared to death. This is the real Jon (when he is with Arya, Sansa and Sam.) Everything else is pretence, IMO. I feel Jon's feeble attempts to defend Dany to Tyrion later have more to do with his identity crisis (that weirdly hasn't been addressed directly).
answer:
2/3 What gets Jon fired up? When Tyrion says Dany’s nature is fire and blood. This upsets Jon NOT because he believes in Dany, but because he feels it’s an attack on him. His defends her because if what Tyrion says is true, then what if he is the same. So he scrambles to make an excuse for her rage. Maybe he’s recalling how he let his rage take over in the past, with Ramsay, LF. If he had a dragon, would he have done the same? Immediately, Tyrion asks if he’d have done the same and Jon falters.

3/3 The show seemed desperate to incorporate “love is death of duty” here, but it doesn’t apply. Jon isn’t in love with Dany. Tyrion talks realm, Jon’s own life being in danger, none of which stir him to action. Tyrion then asks about Sansa, similar to Varys with Ned in S1 (“love is death of duty” doesn’t apply here either), which gives Jon pause. He chooses Sansa over Dany. Sansa = familial/romantic love, not duty. Like Ned, this was about love (Sansa) vs honor (killing his kin and Queen).

You’ve hit the nail on the head, anon.

When I watched this episode, I was so disappointed that the leaks were true that I just watched on in exasperation and detachment. And even though I picked up on a few things (like the repeated mention of Sansa affecting Jon, and Jon’s head shake at the claim he loves Dany), I still read the scene like most people did: Jon defended Dany which felt like a complete retcon from what happened in the previous episode and also felt very out of character for Jon.

I was so sick of the show that I didn’t really want to dig deeper, but yesterday I rewatched a few scenes and you’re right. Jon’s defending himself.

But let’s rewind. I’d like to go through the scenes before we reach the makeshift cell scene, because those scenes should inform how we read Jon’s interactions with Tyrion and Dany later. Jon keeps showing us that he doesn’t agree with her actions, after all.

(Oh, and this will be long, but it has visual aids. Yay?)

In 8.05 Jon sort of goes against order. Granted, Dany never commanded him to keep fighting, but she keeps fighting and Grey Worm keeps fighting. If Jon really truly followed Dany, he would keep fighting too. But his morals stop him. He sheathes his sword and tries getting everyone out of the city.

Then 8.06 starts. We follow Tyrion (with Jon and Davos close behind) walking back into King’s Landing on a street littered with corpses and ashes and crumbled buildings. They stop at the charred remains of the mother and child Arya tried to help. The little girl still holding her toy horse. Tyrion tells Jon he’ll find him later to which Jon replies, “It’s not safe. Let me send some men with you.”

Why isn’t it safe? We don’t know whether Tyrion has told Jon about Jaime, but it’s most likely common knowledge by now and Tyrion did include Davos in his betrayal. It was from Davos Tyrion asked the favor to help in smuggling Cersei and Jaime to Pentos. We don’t need to see Davos and Tyrion telling Jon. It’s implied that he knows. And when Tyrion tells Jon, “I’m going alone,” and Jon follows him with his eyes as Tyrion leaves, the look on Jon’s face also implies he knows that Tyrion will try to find out whether his family made it out. Jon’s not afraid that a King’s Landing survivor will attack Tyrion; Jon is afraid of what Dany will do if she gets her hands on Tyrion. And Jon sending men with Tyrion to protect him is also defying Dany.

After this, Jon interrupts Grey Worm while the latter sentences prisoners of war to die in the name of his queen. Both Jon and Davos argue for the prisoners to remain alive; however, GW has different orders.

GW: “I obey my queen’s commands, not yours.”
Jon: “And what are the queen’s commands?”
GW: “Kill all who follow Cersei Lannister.”

Jon physically stops Grey Worm from following these orders and once more Jon defies Dany. Everyone around them draws their weapons. Jon and Grey Worm enter a staring match, and it’s Davos who brings Jon back by telling him they need to speak to the queen. And yet it still takes Jon a long moment to step back. He glances at the prisoners, deliberating, looks back at GW. He doesn’t want to let GW kill them, but he also knows that if he and his men engage in a battle against the Unsullied, Jon puts even more people at risk. Especially his family, who’ll suffer if Dany learns that Jon fought her men. So he makes his decision and walks away.

As he walks through the square, surrounded by Dothraki, low and dark music drones ominously in the background. Jon looks hard. He glares up at the stairs where the Targaryen banner is hung. Drogon and his rider fly above. 

Jon stares up at them with an expression that shows us his real feelings for Dany–and they sure as hell aren’t warm. Nor is he heartbroken because he was wrong about the ~love of his life~. The tension in his mouth doesn’t quite reach Jon Snow Growl status, but it’s not far from it.

I think Jon knew that he was heading into a situation that would end with bloodshed in some way or another and he was preparing himself mentally. Grey Worm has kept an eye on Jon’s treasonous behavior. He will report to his queen first chance he gets–and Jon and Dany have a strained relationship as it is. But Jon can’t run away either. If he does, Dany will fly after him or even attack his home and his family. All he can do is move forward and try working out a plan.

Dany holds her terrifying speech and we get a reaction shot of Jon watching her with a dark look in his eyes. It’s in these moments–when she can’t see his face–we’re allowed to see Jon’s true feelings. There’s no love in his eyes. No heartbreak. Not until she mentions Winterfell and we see Jon realizing what this means.

This is where Jon’s emotions peek through. His love and worry for his family. No, he doesn’t speak Valyrian but he’s not stupid. He knows what this means.

Tyrion is accused of treason in front of Jon (another reminder of what happens to those who favor family over Dany), throws away his Hand pin, and, as he’s led away, exchanges a pointed look with Jon.

Then Jon and Dany exchange a look. A long look. One that, perhaps, was supposed to make us worried she’d have Jon escorted off to a cell too. But she only stares at him with contempt before leaving (which makes her quick change in mood later rather odd but, well, apparently EC disagrees). As she walks away, Jon does not follow the ~love of his life~ with his eyes. Not until she and the Unsullied have safely passed him does he turn around and glare at her.

He loathes her. I think even looking at her leaves him with a bad taste in his mouth. There’s nothing about his behavior that suggests to me that this is a guy who just realized the woman of his dreams was a monster. He knew. Perhaps not that she was quite this much of a monster. But he knew.

After Arya pops up out of nowhere, they have a conversation about Dany. Arya calls Dany Jon’s queen (as she often does) and Jon replies with, “She’s everyone’s queen now.” His voice is gravelly and the way he delivers it, it’s clear he doesn’t think that’s a good thing. It’s clear he and Arya stand on one side, and Dany on the other. He could just as well have said, “Welcome to hell.” That’s the kind of delivery he gives.

What follows next has annoyed me and others, because Arya says two things to Jon that Tyrion repeats in the makeshift cell scene. It annoyed me and others because why repeat it? What’s the point?

Contrast.

Jon reacts one way to Arya and a whole different way to Tyrion. It’s not inconsistency but a chance for us to compare the real Jon (with Arya) and political!Jon/sacrifical!jon (with Tyrion). It’s not well-written, to be clear, but I do believe this is why they did it. Their clumsy way of giving clues.

When Arya points out Sansa won’t ever bend to Dany, Jon doesn’t protest. He knows it’s true. He doesn’t say that Sansa doesn’t get to choose. He doesn’t say anything at all. He knows it’s true and he knows what it means. He’s tried avoiding confrontation with Dany because she’s a dangerous woman to confront, but it’s now become unavoidable. She mentioned Winterfell in her speech. She hates Sansa. She knows Sansa spread her secret. It’s only a matter of time.

I’m still not entirely sure what Jon’s plan was here, but when he tells Arya to wait for him outside the city gates, I think he was a man on a mission already. Perhaps he was considering killing Drogon (which would leave Dany just another regular foe. Her armies against his). Perhaps he would make things up as he went along.

Perhaps he even realizes that he needs to kill Dany. Perhaps he’s prepared to do it.

But before he can leave, Arya stops him and points out another thing, “Jon. She knows who you are. Who you really are. You’ll always be a threat to her.“

Jon doesn’t comment on this either. He doesn’t say it’s Dany’s right to kill him. He doesn’t defend Dany. He only sighs. This is the real Jon. Jon does not believe that Dany would be in the right. Not at all.

They keep showing us how Jon feels about her. When Dany can’t see him, Jon shows his true feelings. Anger, fear, contempt, disapproval. They show us repeatedly in this episode that Jon would never defend Dany’s actions. Which leads us to the scene where Jon defends Dany’s actions. :)

The Jon who walks into Tyrion’s cell isn’t in “let’s defend Dany!” mode. When Tyrion says he betrayed his queen, Jon tells him he didn’t because contrary to what the characters and the cast and the crew try telling us constantly, Jon isn’t so far up Dany’s ass that he can’t tell right from wrong anymore. Tyrion released his brother. Jon would’ve done the same. 

“And I’d do it again,” Tyrion says, “now that I’ve seen what I’ve seen. I chose my fate. The people of King’s Landing did not.”

“I can’t justify what happened,” Jon says. “I won’t try.”

Looking at Jon’s expression he’s heartbroken over what happened in King’s Landing. He’s most likely still struggling to fully process it and also wondering how much of it is his fault. “Let it be fear,” she said because he couldn’t love her and she sure as hell showed them fear. It’s in no way Jon’s fault, but what person wouldn’t blame themselves on at least some level?

Then Tyrion points out the war is far from over:

T: “She liberated the people of Slaver’s Bay. She liberated the people of King’s Landing. And she’ll go on liberating until the people of the world are free and she rules them all.”

J: “And you’ve been by her side, counseling her. Until today.”

T: ″Until today.”

Jon doesn’t hide is disapproval at Tyrion having been Dany’s Hand. 

Look at the guy. Jon is judging Tyrion. Please look at this gif and tell me that Jon–the real Jon (because this is the real Jon, for once)–would actually defend Dany. There’s even a hint of an incredulous amusement, as if he thinks Tyrion is a god damn hypocrite and he can’t believe the words coming out of the guy’s mouth.

Jon seems to think, “If you knew all along what she is, then why the hell did you help her in invading Westeros? Why did you snitch on Varys when Varys was trying to stop her?” And it’s easy for Jon to judge. He got involved with Dany because death was coming and he believed he needed her dragons and her armies to stop it. He did what he had to to save everyone he loves and, you know, the world. And he’s stayed by Dany’s side because he needed to protect his family from her. What was Tyrion’s excuse?

Then comes the complete switch in Jon’s attitude. The switch that you, anon, brought up: Tyrion makes this about House words. He makes it about blood.

T: “Our queen’s nature is fire and blood–”

J: “You think our house words are stamped on our bodies when we’re born and that’s who we are? Then I’d be fire and blood too.“

“Then I’d be fire and blood too.”

Finally, Jon’s identity crisis is addressed: he’s triggered by the suggestion that he and Dany could be the same.

Unfortunately, this is not just way too damn late. It’s also badly written because it’s so very contrived.

I think this scene mostly exists for two reasons: they needed someone to explain to the audience why assassinating Dany was justified, to point out that this is her pattern, and make sure we all knew that she needed to be stopped. Which is hamfisted and insulting to the audience’s intelligence. But they also wanted to actually insult their audience by pointing out that those of us who’ve cheered Dany on were part of the problem. We’ve accepted her horrible deeds without questioning. We’ve cheered her on and she’s grown stronger and stronger as an icon until she became the face of this show. They’re basically slapping their audience in the face for drinking the koolaid they gave us.

But they’re also asking a rather interesting question that, in better hands, could’ve made this scene very compelling: if it were you, if you were the one with almost unlimited power, would you be any better?

If you could round up really bad criminals and burn them alive without repercussions, would you do it? Would you do it even if you weren’t 100% sure everyone was guilty? If someone told you 9 out of 10 were guilty of human trafficking but that one was innocent and you couldn’t know whom, would you still do it? Would you think that sacrificing one person to make the world a better place would be worth it?

Daenerys thinks so. She would sacrifice thousands. Possibly even millions. But would you? Would Jon? Another Targaryen who has ridden dragons and who has an inner beast that appears every so often. When he killed Janos Slynt, when he beat Ramsay to a pulp, when he throttled Littlefinger.

Jon is a hot-headed guy and a killer and a Targaryen. And now he’s facing a very important question: If Dany is a monster because she’s fire and blood, then what does that make Jon? If Dany is her father, then what does that make Jon?

His biological father was hardly an admirable man. He abandoned his wife and children for a teenager to fulfill a prophecy, something Jon would never ever do. And yet he has spent the last few weeks lying to his family while banging a woman he doesn’t love just to get her dragons. Something Ned Stark would never do, but perhaps Rhaegar would.

When Jon defends Dany by giving weak excuses, he’s not actually defending Dany. He’s doing his best not to examine or even acknowledge his identity crisis, because that would mean examining himself and the things he’s done he’s not proud of. He’d have to wonder: is this the Targaryen in me?

“I’m tired of fighting. It’s all I’ve done since I left home. I’ve killed brothers of the Night’s Watch. I’ve killed wildlings. I’ve killed men that I admire. I hanged a boy younger than Bran.“

And he’s killed on the battlefield. He’s most likely lost count of how many men he’s killed by now. And he knows well how rage can take over, how blood lust can take over until you’re completely lost. The way he just saw his men lose it when they started attacking anything that moved despite the bells sounding out surrender.

“Aye, it’s easy to judge when you’re standing far from the battlefield.“

Then Tyrion says something that catches Jon off guard completely. The thing Jon doesn’t want to ask himself: ”Would you have done it?”

Jon is taken aback at first. Then he claims he doesn’t know, but I think he does know. Of course he wouldn’t have burned down King’s Landing. He doesn’t trust Tyrion, though, and won’t speak openly with him. But I think the biggest reason is Doylist: they wanted Tyrion to spell out for the audience that, even when Dany punished bad men, she did it in horrible ways and that it all contributed to her getting a very skewed view of justice. It’s weak writing, but they needed to make a point–and they needed to show us the difference between Jon and Dany.

Tyrion: “Everywhere she goes, evil men die and we cheer her for it. And she grows more powerful and more sure that she is good and right. She believes her destiny is to build a better world for everyone. If you believed that if you truly believed it, wouldn’t you kill whoever stood between you and paradise?“

Here’s the thing: Tyrion explains to us–and to Jon–that Dany killed (without a trial) men who’d done awful things (slavers). He explains to us–and to Jon–that Dany killed men before they did awful things (the khals). And isn’t that exactly what Tyrion now wants Jon to do? 

Isn’t that what Jon has been wrestling with the whole episode so far? (And will keep wrestling with.)

He needs to stop Dany. But he probably can’t defeat her in a way that leads to a trial. He can’t kill her in an honorable way or even have someone else do it with a hanging or a beheading. He’ll need to assassinate her. So, again, what does that make him? How is he better than she is? 

Yes, he’d be doing it for the greater good, but isn’t that what she believes she has done so far?

So how does that make Jon better?

Perhaps Jon was determined to kill Dany earlier, but now, by trying to encourage Jon to do it, Tyrion actually gives Jon doubts. Which isn’t that odd. Jon could’ve let his rage carry him, but now Tyrion invites him to actually examine the action long before Jon can go through with it. 

But Tyrion–who’s in love with Dany–doesn’t understand why Jon hesitates. He thinks Jon is loyal and in love, but when Tyrion says, “I know you love her,” Jon looks annoyed. Even angry. Provoked.

We’ve seen this reaction of his before. Many times. Here’s another example:

Jon doesn’t love Dany. He’s sick of pretending he does. I bet a huge part of him wants to scream, “I DON’T!” But he can’t. Because he doesn’t trust Tyrion and he’s been keeping this secret for so long that telling it now, in this situation and to this man, would be the dumbest thing he could do.

I really do think that Jon’s biggest struggle here is that he doesn’t want to assassinate an essentially defenseless woman (because without her dragon and her armies, she is). A woman he’s related to, a woman who loves him, a woman he’s been manipulating for a long while. Dany is abusive toward him, but the world he lives in is completely unaware of that being a thing. In the world he lives in, killing a woman in cold blood is dishonorable and evil. It’s against his moral code.

He’s also pledged himself to her (duty) and now he’s facing having to kill her to protect his family (love). Love is the death of duty, he says, because he and Tyrion are having somewhat different conversations since Jon doesn’t tell Tyrion the truth. So Tyrion (and we) keep thinking Jon’s romantic feelings for Dany is clashing with his sense telling him she needs to be stopped, when I think Jon’s having a big ass identity crisis. Not just an identity crisis because of his Targaryen blood, but also about who he’ll be if he kills Dany the way he knows he must. Not on a battlefield but in a quiet, possibly even intimate moment. It’s the only way he can get close enough.

Then Tyrion speaks a bit more plainly.

“It’s a terrible thing I’m asking. It’s also the right thing. Do you think I’m the last man she’ll execute? Who is more dangerous than the rightful heir to the Iron Throne?“

There’s a huge shift in Jon’s demeanor here. You literally see him slipping back into “Whatever my queen commands, I will obey” mode. 

Even Tyrion’s all, dude wtf? But Jon has to slip back into this role. This isn’t whipped!Jon. This is terrified Jon. Tyrion’s asking Jon to commit treason. A word that’s kept popping up this season–and Jon made it clear how much it frightened him as early as in 8.01.

Outside wait guards who (as they established in 8.05) speak the Common Tongue. They could be listening in on every word they say. And even if they don’t overhear, what if Tyrion is playing the game? Jon doesn’t trust him. Tyrion lured him into a trap. He ratted out his best friend. He put Sansa at risk. He stood by Dany’s side as she invaded Westeros. What if he tells on Jon too? Just to save himself. I think Jon does like Tyrion but trust? No.

If Dany in any way suspects that Jon isn’t loyal to her, she’ll jump aboard that dragon of hers and burn down Winterfell. Jon can’t risk setting her off.

Compare this to Jon’s reaction when Arya said the same. It’s not similar in the slightest. With Arya, we saw the real Jon. Here, we don’t. We see the Jon most of s8 has given us: Dany’s obedient servant. The Jon who shuts Sansa up in a meeting because that’s the only way he thinks he can be the shield between Dany and the people he loves. 

After this Jon tries leaving the room. This is getting too dangerous. But Tyrion doesn’t understand Jon. Tyrion still thinks he needs to convince Jon that Dany is dangerous, so he pulls the family card.

T: “And your sisters? Do you see them bending the knee?”

J: “My sisters will be loyal to the throne.”

T: “Why do you think Sansa told me the truth about you? Because she doesn’t want Dany to be queen.”

J: “She doesn’t get to choose.”

T: “No. But you do.”

Again: compare this to Jon’s behavior with Arya. He said nothing of the sort because he didn’t have to protect Sansa with lies when talking to Arya. This is Jon terrified of saying the wrong thing. This is “I’m loyal to my beloved Joffrey” Jon. And, yes, it’s bad writing. It is. They’re straining to keep up the ruse up until the last minute. They don’t want us to think that Jon is walking into the throne room determined to kill Dany. Even though Jon looked ready to assassinate her or at least betray her in some way earlier in the episode–or perhaps because he did–they now need to make us doubt that he’d ever go against her. And they needed to get in the line, “She doesn’t get to choose,” so that Dany’s line later, “They don’t get to choose,” makes it clear why Jon finally takes the plunge.

Sansa was always supposed to be the final trigger. But instead of making that explicit throughout the season (most likely because then it wouldn’t be as surprising), they did this.

When Jon stalks toward the throne room, I do think he’s already more or less made up his mind. He probably made it up earlier that day. But I also think he struggles with the decision because he thinks that, if he does it, he won’t make it out alive. He’ll never see his family again. He might even start a war between the Unsullied/Dothraki and the Northmen and KotV waiting outside the city gates. He knows it’s a dishonorable act. He knows Ned Stark would’ve found another way. 

Jon’s behavior once in the throne room is almost like the different stages of grief: denial, anger, bargaining, depression, acceptance. (And, again, I don’t think it’s because he loves her; it’s because of what he has to do and what it makes him.) Previously, even though he’s probably always known deep down that one day it would come to this, he’s been in denial. He’s done his very best to take the easy way out, to not confront, to hope he can keep mollifying her, but now he walks in angry.

While she’s gushing about the Iron Throne as if she didn’t just slaughtered a few hundred thousand people or so, Jon confronts her for the first time since… 7.04? Possibly 7.05 when he questioned her using Drogon on the battlefield. And I don’t think Jon would’ve done that if he believed Dany would leave that room alive. It’s much too dangerous. He’s avoided confronting her thus far for a reason.

And, remember, he just defended this act of hers to Tyrion. But now they’re letting us see how Jon really feels.

J: “I saw them executing Lannister prisoners in the street. They said they were acting on your orders.”

D: “It was necessary.”

J: “Necessary? Have you been down there? Have you seen? Children, little children, burned!”

D: “I tried to make peace with Cersei. She used their innocence as a weapon against me. She thought it would cripple me.”

A terrifying thing to say. It should’ve stayed Dany’s hand. And Jon knows it’s useless to argue, so he moves on and it leads to bargaining.

J: “And Tyrion?”

D: “He conspired behind my back with my enemies. How have you treated people who’ve done the same to you, even when it broke your heart?”

J: “Forgive him.”

D: “I can’t.”

J: “You can. You can forgive all of them, make them see they made a mistake. Make them understand. Please, Dany.”

What I think Jon is pleading for here isn’t that Dany forgives everyone. I think Jon’s desperately pleading for her to give him a reason to not go through with what he came to the throne room to do. He doesn’t want to kill her. He doesn’t. And especially not this way. It’s so easy for us to sit at home and judge and say KILL HER KILL HER. I sure as hell have said it. But would we be able to do it? In self-defense, maybe, but just walk up to her and stab her in the heart? I’m not sure I could’ve done it.

Yes, Jon has killed people before but only men. Women he’s avoided killing. Even when he banished Melisandre, he said that if she were to return to the North, he’d have her hanged as a murdered. Have her hanged = he wouldn’t do it himself. He couldn’t kill Ygritte. And this is complicated too. Dany is his blood. She is his family, in a way. And so the pleading goes on until we land here:

D: “It’s not easy to see something that’s never been before: a good world.”

J: “How do you know? How do you know it’ll be good?”

D: “Because I know what is good. And so do you.”

J: “I don’t.”

“I don’t,” he says because he’s thinking of what he has to do. He doesn’t know whether killing Dany in cold blood, in this moment where she’s happy and not putting anyone in immediate danger or hurting anyone, would be a good act. It might be necessary. Tyrion certainly seems to think so. But, again, isn’t that the excuse Dany uses? What would Ned Stark do? Would he find a better solution? A good solution. A fair and just (albeit riskier) solution. He would have, wouldn’t he?

Jon’s crying and lost. The depression stage. Where he should’ve received comfort, but instead Dany as always tries manipulating him into agreeing with her. She’s touching him–a hand on his chest, a hand on his shoulder–while he stands there passive. Struggling. Wrapping his head around what to do. On how to justify it to himself. He needs a trigger. And she gives him one – “They don’t get to choose.” – and you see the moment he realizes that he has to do it. 

There is no reasoning with her. He can’t control her with soft manipulation anymore. Burning down King’s Landing didn’t horrify her; it encouraged her. Every time she doles out her own brand of justice, it makes her more sure she’s right and good. Just like Tyrion said.

I think Jon knows now–that he accepts now–what he has to do. He’s not Ned Stark’s son. He’s not honorable. But he is the shield that guards the realms of men. And he is the man who’d kill to protect his family. 

Drogon is close by. They had a staring match before Jon entered the throne room. Jon has ridden Rhaegal. He knows about the bond, how a dragon can follow its rider’s unspoken commands. The moment Dany suspects something’s wrong, Drogon will act. She can’t suspect anything’s wrong.

So Jon lets her move in close. He lets her take his hand and put it on her cheek. When she asks him to break the wheel with her–basically a proposal–he gives her the only words he can. Not a yes. Not “I love you” because he doesn’t. He can’t tell her that; she’d know he’s lying and then the opportunity’s gone. She’s not love. She’s duty. He’s pledged himself to her. So he says: “You are my queen. Now and always.” An answer that pleases her. An answer she takes as a yes.

She moves in for the kiss. He stands completely still and lets it happen. And right before her lips touch his, his hand moves for the dagger.

I don’t like these writing choices, to be clear. They’re awful. It’s obvious that D&D wanted us to keep guessing up until Jon’s hand moved to his dagger. I’d read the leaks so I knew, but imagine if you hadn’t. I watched a reaction video the other day and people had a strong, negative reaction when they thought Jon said yes to Dany’s proposal–and then they cheered when he stabbed her. A room full of people who previously had cheered Dany on when she burned the Lannister army now cheered when Jon murdered her. This is what D&D wanted and so Jon’s characterization had to suffer. They decided to write a scene where he had to murder her while kissing her and it’s gross as hell. But this was the best way they knew how to shock us.

They also needed to show us that Jon is the opposite of Dany. They’ve been foils the whole series and with Tyrion’s comments earlier and Jon’s hesitation now, they’re making it clear once and for all: Dany would’ve done it. If she believed Jon was an evil man, she would’ve murdered him without hesitation and without regret. She kills and kills and kills and never questions the decision. It’s righteous. It’s just. It’s necessary.

So Jon has to question it. Jon’s instinct has to be to find a way out of it. To find a more peaceful solution, like his real father Ned Stark would’ve done. Because Jon isn’t fire and blood. He’s not Dany or Aerys.

And he has to be torn up about it too. He has to stare at her in shock, he has to cry, he has to ask Tyrion much later whether what they did was the right thing to do. He can’t be like Littlefinger who happily flings Lysa out the Moon Door after telling her the truth about his feelings. Jon’s our hero not a villain.

And yet Jon killed a woman. A woman he was related to, who loved him, who wanted him by her side, who believed he loved her back when he only ever used her, who lost so much because he used her, who chose fear because he couldn’t love her…   (No, I don’t think either is Jon’s fault, but I’m not so sure he would agree with me.)

So by murdering her this way, not in the heat of battle, not to stop her from actively hurting someone, not even by executing her after a fair trial, but as a precautionary measure, what does that make him?

A hero or a monster?

It’s an excellent question. Something that warrants a lot of discussion about ethics and morals. Something that could’ve made this episode very interesting had D&D actually had the guts to explore it. If they had let Jon speak openly with someone and confess that he didn’t love Dany, open up about his feelings and thoughts, this could’ve changed the whole season.

But instead they chose the very bloody version of will they/won’t they. They wanted us to be unsure of whether Jon would give in to the love they’ve tried to sell us (but Jon doesn’t actually feel) and rule by her side, or whether he would go against his own moral code and murder a woman. And now that I’ve seen the whole season, I can’t help but think that’s the main reason why Jnerys even existed in the first place. To make this murder into a really gross and horrible twist.

I know everyone and their gerbil tell us Jon loves Dany, that she’s the love of his life, that they’re star-crossed lovers and what have you. But I never saw him fall in love. I never saw him be happy with her (while I saw him being happy with everyone else). I only saw fear and annoyance and anger and obedience and playing a role. The cast telling me Jon loved her is not enough to change that. Tyrion thinking Jon loved Dany is not enough to change that. Jon crying over her dead body is not enough to change that. Isolated, that scene could’ve looked as if he loved her, but looking at this whole episode…? Looking at all of s8 and s7? It just does not make sense to me. 

I don’t know whether they filmed different versions of the assassination scene. I don’t know whether they retconned it late in the process and asked for reshoots and did the best they could with the editing. I don’t know whether they always wanted to keep it ambiguous. I don’t even know whether they went for starcrossed lovers and just failed epically. All of them. Except Ramin Djawadi lmao. All I know is that I never saw Jon loving Dany and so I can’t believe it.

So this is my take. This is how I make sense of Jon’s characterization, which seemingly only ever existed because of a twist. As infuriating as that is.

Thanks for the ask!
answer_abstract:
2/3 What gets Jon fired up? When Tyrion says Dany’s nature is fire and blood. This upsets Jon NOT because he believes in Dany, but because he feels it’s an attack on him. His defends her because if what Tyrion says is true, then what if he is the same. So he scrambles to make an excuse for her rage. Maybe he’s recalling how he let his rage take over in the past, with Ramsay, LF. If he had a dragon, would he have done the same? Immediately, Tyrion asks if he’d have done the same and Jon falters.

3/3 The show seemed desperate to incorporate “love is death of duty” here, but it doesn’t apply. Jon isn’t in love with Dany. Tyrion talks realm, Jon’s own life being in danger, none of which stir him to action. Tyrion then asks about Sansa, similar to Varys with Ned in S1 (“love is death of duty” doesn’t apply here either), which gives Jon pause. He chooses Sansa over Dany. Sansa = familial/romantic love, not duty. Like Ned, this was about love (Sansa) vs honor (killing his kin and Queen).

You’ve hit the nail on the head, anon.

When I watched this episode, I was so disappointed that the leaks were true that I just watched on in exasperation and detachment. And even though I picked up on a few things (like the repeated mention of Sansa affecting Jon, and Jon’s head shake at the claim he loves Dany), I still read the scene like most people did: Jon defended Dany which felt like a complete retcon from what happened in the previous episode and also felt very out of character for Jon.

I was so sick of the show that I didn’t really want to dig deeper, but yesterday I rewatched a few scenes and you’re right. Jon’s defending himself.

But let’s rewind. I’d like to go through the scenes before we reach the makeshift cell scene, because those scenes should inform how we read Jon’s interactions with Tyrion and Dany later. Jon keeps showing us that he doesn’t agree with her actions, after all.

(Oh, and this will be long, but it has visual aids. Yay?)

reblog.comment:
2/3 What gets Jon fired up? When Tyrion says Dany’s nature is fire and blood. This upsets Jon NOT because he believes in Dany, but because he feels it’s an attack on him. His defends her because if what Tyrion says is true, then what if he is the same. So he scrambles to make an excuse for her rage. Maybe he’s recalling how he let his rage take over in the past, with Ramsay, LF. If he had a dragon, would he have done the same? Immediately, Tyrion asks if he’d have done the same and Jon falters.

3/3 The show seemed desperate to incorporate “love is death of duty” here, but it doesn’t apply. Jon isn’t in love with Dany. Tyrion talks realm, Jon’s own life being in danger, none of which stir him to action. Tyrion then asks about Sansa, similar to Varys with Ned in S1 (“love is death of duty” doesn’t apply here either), which gives Jon pause. He chooses Sansa over Dany. Sansa = familial/romantic love, not duty. Like Ned, this was about love (Sansa) vs honor (killing his kin and Queen).

You’ve hit the nail on the head, anon.

When I watched this episode, I was so disappointed that the leaks were true that I just watched on in exasperation and detachment. And even though I picked up on a few things (like the repeated mention of Sansa affecting Jon, and Jon’s head shake at the claim he loves Dany), I still read the scene like most people did: Jon defended Dany which felt like a complete retcon from what happened in the previous episode and also felt very out of character for Jon.

I was so sick of the show that I didn’t really want to dig deeper, but yesterday I rewatched a few scenes and you’re right. Jon’s defending himself.

But let’s rewind. I’d like to go through the scenes before we reach the makeshift cell scene, because those scenes should inform how we read Jon’s interactions with Tyrion and Dany later. Jon keeps showing us that he doesn’t agree with her actions, after all.

(Oh, and this will be long, but it has visual aids. Yay?)

[[MORE]]

In 8.05 Jon sort of goes against order. Granted, Dany never commanded him to keep fighting, but she keeps fighting and Grey Worm keeps fighting. If Jon really truly followed Dany, he would keep fighting too. But his morals stop him. He sheathes his sword and tries getting everyone out of the city.

Then 8.06 starts. We follow Tyrion (with Jon and Davos close behind) walking back into King’s Landing on a street littered with corpses and ashes and crumbled buildings. They stop at the charred remains of the mother and child Arya tried to help. The little girl still holding her toy horse. Tyrion tells Jon he’ll find him later to which Jon replies, “It’s not safe. Let me send some men with you.”

Why isn’t it safe? We don’t know whether Tyrion has told Jon about Jaime, but it’s most likely common knowledge by now and Tyrion did include Davos in his betrayal. It was from Davos Tyrion asked the favor to help in smuggling Cersei and Jaime to Pentos. We don’t need to see Davos and Tyrion telling Jon. It’s implied that he knows. And when Tyrion tells Jon, “I’m going alone,” and Jon follows him with his eyes as Tyrion leaves, the look on Jon’s face also implies he knows that Tyrion will try to find out whether his family made it out. Jon’s not afraid that a King’s Landing survivor will attack Tyrion; Jon is afraid of what Dany will do if she gets her hands on Tyrion. And Jon sending men with Tyrion to protect him is also defying Dany.

After this, Jon interrupts Grey Worm while the latter sentences prisoners of war to die in the name of his queen. Both Jon and Davos argue for the prisoners to remain alive; however, GW has different orders.

GW: “I obey my queen’s commands, not yours.”
Jon: “And what are the queen’s commands?”
GW: “Kill all who follow Cersei Lannister.”

Jon physically stops Grey Worm from following these orders and once more Jon defies Dany. Everyone around them draws their weapons. Jon and Grey Worm enter a staring match, and it’s Davos who brings Jon back by telling him they need to speak to the queen. And yet it still takes Jon a long moment to step back. He glances at the prisoners, deliberating, looks back at GW. He doesn’t want to let GW kill them, but he also knows that if he and his men engage in a battle against the Unsullied, Jon puts even more people at risk. Especially his family, who’ll suffer if Dany learns that Jon fought her men. So he makes his decision and walks away.

As he walks through the square, surrounded by Dothraki, low and dark music drones ominously in the background. Jon looks hard. He glares up at the stairs where the Targaryen banner is hung. Drogon and his rider fly above. 

Jon stares up at them with an expression that shows us his real feelings for Dany–and they sure as hell aren’t warm. Nor is he heartbroken because he was wrong about the ~love of his life~. The tension in his mouth doesn’t quite reach Jon Snow Growl status, but it’s not far from it.

I think Jon knew that he was heading into a situation that would end with bloodshed in some way or another and he was preparing himself mentally. Grey Worm has kept an eye on Jon’s treasonous behavior. He will report to his queen first chance he gets–and Jon and Dany have a strained relationship as it is. But Jon can’t run away either. If he does, Dany will fly after him or even attack his home and his family. All he can do is move forward and try working out a plan.

Dany holds her terrifying speech and we get a reaction shot of Jon watching her with a dark look in his eyes. It’s in these moments–when she can’t see his face–we’re allowed to see Jon’s true feelings. There’s no love in his eyes. No heartbreak. Not until she mentions Winterfell and we see Jon realizing what this means.

This is where Jon’s emotions peek through. His love and worry for his family. No, he doesn’t speak Valyrian but he’s not stupid. He knows what this means.

Tyrion is accused of treason in front of Jon (another reminder of what happens to those who favor family over Dany), throws away his Hand pin, and, as he’s led away, exchanges a pointed look with Jon.

Then Jon and Dany exchange a look. A long look. One that, perhaps, was supposed to make us worried she’d have Jon escorted off to a cell too. But she only stares at him with contempt before leaving (which makes her quick change in mood later rather odd but, well, apparently EC disagrees). As she walks away, Jon does not follow the ~love of his life~ with his eyes. Not until she and the Unsullied have safely passed him does he turn around and glare at her.

He loathes her. I think even looking at her leaves him with a bad taste in his mouth. There’s nothing about his behavior that suggests to me that this is a guy who just realized the woman of his dreams was a monster. He knew. Perhaps not that she was quite this much of a monster. But he knew.

After Arya pops up out of nowhere, they have a conversation about Dany. Arya calls Dany Jon’s queen (as she often does) and Jon replies with, “She’s everyone’s queen now.” His voice is gravelly and the way he delivers it, it’s clear he doesn’t think that’s a good thing. It’s clear he and Arya stand on one side, and Dany on the other. He could just as well have said, “Welcome to hell.” That’s the kind of delivery he gives.

What follows next has annoyed me and others, because Arya says two things to Jon that Tyrion repeats in the makeshift cell scene. It annoyed me and others because why repeat it? What’s the point?

Contrast.

Jon reacts one way to Arya and a whole different way to Tyrion. It’s not inconsistency but a chance for us to compare the real Jon (with Arya) and political!Jon/sacrifical!jon (with Tyrion). It’s not well-written, to be clear, but I do believe this is why they did it. Their clumsy way of giving clues.

When Arya points out Sansa won’t ever bend to Dany, Jon doesn’t protest. He knows it’s true. He doesn’t say that Sansa doesn’t get to choose. He doesn’t say anything at all. He knows it’s true and he knows what it means. He’s tried avoiding confrontation with Dany because she’s a dangerous woman to confront, but it’s now become unavoidable. She mentioned Winterfell in her speech. She hates Sansa. She knows Sansa spread her secret. It’s only a matter of time.

I’m still not entirely sure what Jon’s plan was here, but when he tells Arya to wait for him outside the city gates, I think he was a man on a mission already. Perhaps he was considering killing Drogon (which would leave Dany just another regular foe. Her armies against his). Perhaps he would make things up as he went along.

Perhaps he even realizes that he needs to kill Dany. Perhaps he’s prepared to do it.

But before he can leave, Arya stops him and points out another thing, “Jon. She knows who you are. Who you really are. You’ll always be a threat to her.“

Jon doesn’t comment on this either. He doesn’t say it’s Dany’s right to kill him. He doesn’t defend Dany. He only sighs. This is the real Jon. Jon does not believe that Dany would be in the right. Not at all.

They keep showing us how Jon feels about her. When Dany can’t see him, Jon shows his true feelings. Anger, fear, contempt, disapproval. They show us repeatedly in this episode that Jon would never defend Dany’s actions. Which leads us to the scene where Jon defends Dany’s actions. :)

The Jon who walks into Tyrion’s cell isn’t in “let’s defend Dany!” mode. When Tyrion says he betrayed his queen, Jon tells him he didn’t because contrary to what the characters and the cast and the crew try telling us constantly, Jon isn’t so far up Dany’s ass that he can’t tell right from wrong anymore. Tyrion released his brother. Jon would’ve done the same. 

“And I’d do it again,” Tyrion says, “now that I’ve seen what I’ve seen. I chose my fate. The people of King’s Landing did not.”

“I can’t justify what happened,” Jon says. “I won’t try.”

Looking at Jon’s expression he’s heartbroken over what happened in King’s Landing. He’s most likely still struggling to fully process it and also wondering how much of it is his fault. “Let it be fear,” she said because he couldn’t love her and she sure as hell showed them fear. It’s in no way Jon’s fault, but what person wouldn’t blame themselves on at least some level?

Then Tyrion points out the war is far from over:

T: “She liberated the people of Slaver’s Bay. She liberated the people of King’s Landing. And she’ll go on liberating until the people of the world are free and she rules them all.”

J: “And you’ve been by her side, counseling her. Until today.”

T: ″Until today.”

Jon doesn’t hide is disapproval at Tyrion having been Dany’s Hand. 

Look at the guy. Jon is judging Tyrion. Please look at this gif and tell me that Jon–the real Jon (because this is the real Jon, for once)–would actually defend Dany. There’s even a hint of an incredulous amusement, as if he thinks Tyrion is a god damn hypocrite and he can’t believe the words coming out of the guy’s mouth.

Jon seems to think, “If you knew all along what she is, then why the hell did you help her in invading Westeros? Why did you snitch on Varys when Varys was trying to stop her?” And it’s easy for Jon to judge. He got involved with Dany because death was coming and he believed he needed her dragons and her armies to stop it. He did what he had to to save everyone he loves and, you know, the world. And he’s stayed by Dany’s side because he needed to protect his family from her. What was Tyrion’s excuse?

Then comes the complete switch in Jon’s attitude. The switch that you, anon, brought up: Tyrion makes this about House words. He makes it about blood.

T: “Our queen’s nature is fire and blood–”

J: “You think our house words are stamped on our bodies when we’re born and that’s who we are? Then I’d be fire and blood too.“

“Then I’d be fire and blood too.”

Finally, Jon’s identity crisis is addressed: he’s triggered by the suggestion that he and Dany could be the same.

Unfortunately, this is not just way too damn late. It’s also badly written because it’s so very contrived.

I think this scene mostly exists for two reasons: they needed someone to explain to the audience why assassinating Dany was justified, to point out that this is her pattern, and make sure we all knew that she needed to be stopped. Which is hamfisted and insulting to the audience’s intelligence. But they also wanted to actually insult their audience by pointing out that those of us who’ve cheered Dany on were part of the problem. We’ve accepted her horrible deeds without questioning. We’ve cheered her on and she’s grown stronger and stronger as an icon until she became the face of this show. They’re basically slapping their audience in the face for drinking the koolaid they gave us.

But they’re also asking a rather interesting question that, in better hands, could’ve made this scene very compelling: if it were you, if you were the one with almost unlimited power, would you be any better?

If you could round up really bad criminals and burn them alive without repercussions, would you do it? Would you do it even if you weren’t 100% sure everyone was guilty? If someone told you 9 out of 10 were guilty of human trafficking but that one was innocent and you couldn’t know whom, would you still do it? Would you think that sacrificing one person to make the world a better place would be worth it?

Daenerys thinks so. She would sacrifice thousands. Possibly even millions. But would you? Would Jon? Another Targaryen who has ridden dragons and who has an inner beast that appears every so often. When he killed Janos Slynt, when he beat Ramsay to a pulp, when he throttled Littlefinger.

Jon is a hot-headed guy and a killer and a Targaryen. And now he’s facing a very important question: If Dany is a monster because she’s fire and blood, then what does that make Jon? If Dany is her father, then what does that make Jon?

His biological father was hardly an admirable man. He abandoned his wife and children for a teenager to fulfill a prophecy, something Jon would never ever do. And yet he has spent the last few weeks lying to his family while banging a woman he doesn’t love just to get her dragons. Something Ned Stark would never do, but perhaps Rhaegar would.

When Jon defends Dany by giving weak excuses, he’s not actually defending Dany. He’s doing his best not to examine or even acknowledge his identity crisis, because that would mean examining himself and the things he’s done he’s not proud of. He’d have to wonder: is this the Targaryen in me?

“I’m tired of fighting. It’s all I’ve done since I left home. I’ve killed brothers of the Night’s Watch. I’ve killed wildlings. I’ve killed men that I admire. I hanged a boy younger than Bran.“

And he’s killed on the battlefield. He’s most likely lost count of how many men he’s killed by now. And he knows well how rage can take over, how blood lust can take over until you’re completely lost. The way he just saw his men lose it when they started attacking anything that moved despite the bells sounding out surrender.

“Aye, it’s easy to judge when you’re standing far from the battlefield.“

Then Tyrion says something that catches Jon off guard completely. The thing Jon doesn’t want to ask himself: ”Would you have done it?”

Jon is taken aback at first. Then he claims he doesn’t know, but I think he does know. Of course he wouldn’t have burned down King’s Landing. He doesn’t trust Tyrion, though, and won’t speak openly with him. But I think the biggest reason is Doylist: they wanted Tyrion to spell out for the audience that, even when Dany punished bad men, she did it in horrible ways and that it all contributed to her getting a very skewed view of justice. It’s weak writing, but they needed to make a point–and they needed to show us the difference between Jon and Dany.

Tyrion: “Everywhere she goes, evil men die and we cheer her for it. And she grows more powerful and more sure that she is good and right. She believes her destiny is to build a better world for everyone. If you believed that if you truly believed it, wouldn’t you kill whoever stood between you and paradise?“

Here’s the thing: Tyrion explains to us–and to Jon–that Dany killed (without a trial) men who’d done awful things (slavers). He explains to us–and to Jon–that Dany killed men before they did awful things (the khals). And isn’t that exactly what Tyrion now wants Jon to do? 

Isn’t that what Jon has been wrestling with the whole episode so far? (And will keep wrestling with.)

He needs to stop Dany. But he probably can’t defeat her in a way that leads to a trial. He can’t kill her in an honorable way or even have someone else do it with a hanging or a beheading. He’ll need to assassinate her. So, again, what does that make him? How is he better than she is? 

Yes, he’d be doing it for the greater good, but isn’t that what she believes she has done so far?

So how does that make Jon better?

Perhaps Jon was determined to kill Dany earlier, but now, by trying to encourage Jon to do it, Tyrion actually gives Jon doubts. Which isn’t that odd. Jon could’ve let his rage carry him, but now Tyrion invites him to actually examine the action long before Jon can go through with it. 

But Tyrion–who’s in love with Dany–doesn’t understand why Jon hesitates. He thinks Jon is loyal and in love, but when Tyrion says, “I know you love her,” Jon looks annoyed. Even angry. Provoked.

We’ve seen this reaction of his before. Many times. Here’s another example:

Jon doesn’t love Dany. He’s sick of pretending he does. I bet a huge part of him wants to scream, “I DON’T!” But he can’t. Because he doesn’t trust Tyrion and he’s been keeping this secret for so long that telling it now, in this situation and to this man, would be the dumbest thing he could do.

I really do think that Jon’s biggest struggle here is that he doesn’t want to assassinate an essentially defenseless woman (because without her dragon and her armies, she is). A woman he’s related to, a woman who loves him, a woman he’s been manipulating for a long while. Dany is abusive toward him, but the world he lives in is completely unaware of that being a thing. In the world he lives in, killing a woman in cold blood is dishonorable and evil. It’s against his moral code.

He’s also pledged himself to her (duty) and now he’s facing having to kill her to protect his family (love). Love is the death of duty, he says, because he and Tyrion are having somewhat different conversations since Jon doesn’t tell Tyrion the truth. So Tyrion (and we) keep thinking Jon’s romantic feelings for Dany is clashing with his sense telling him she needs to be stopped, when I think Jon’s having a big ass identity crisis. Not just an identity crisis because of his Targaryen blood, but also about who he’ll be if he kills Dany the way he knows he must. Not on a battlefield but in a quiet, possibly even intimate moment. It’s the only way he can get close enough.

Then Tyrion speaks a bit more plainly.

“It’s a terrible thing I’m asking. It’s also the right thing. Do you think I’m the last man she’ll execute? Who is more dangerous than the rightful heir to the Iron Throne?“

There’s a huge shift in Jon’s demeanor here. You literally see him slipping back into “Whatever my queen commands, I will obey” mode. 

Even Tyrion’s all, dude wtf? But Jon has to slip back into this role. This isn’t whipped!Jon. This is terrified Jon. Tyrion’s asking Jon to commit treason. A word that’s kept popping up this season–and Jon made it clear how much it frightened him as early as in 8.01.

Outside wait guards who (as they established in 8.05) speak the Common Tongue. They could be listening in on every word they say. And even if they don’t overhear, what if Tyrion is playing the game? Jon doesn’t trust him. Tyrion lured him into a trap. He ratted out his best friend. He put Sansa at risk. He stood by Dany’s side as she invaded Westeros. What if he tells on Jon too? Just to save himself. I think Jon does like Tyrion but trust? No.

If Dany in any way suspects that Jon isn’t loyal to her, she’ll jump aboard that dragon of hers and burn down Winterfell. Jon can’t risk setting her off.

Compare this to Jon’s reaction when Arya said the same. It’s not similar in the slightest. With Arya, we saw the real Jon. Here, we don’t. We see the Jon most of s8 has given us: Dany’s obedient servant. The Jon who shuts Sansa up in a meeting because that’s the only way he thinks he can be the shield between Dany and the people he loves. 

After this Jon tries leaving the room. This is getting too dangerous. But Tyrion doesn’t understand Jon. Tyrion still thinks he needs to convince Jon that Dany is dangerous, so he pulls the family card.

T: “And your sisters? Do you see them bending the knee?”

J: “My sisters will be loyal to the throne.”

T: “Why do you think Sansa told me the truth about you? Because she doesn’t want Dany to be queen.”

J: “She doesn’t get to choose.”

T: “No. But you do.”

Again: compare this to Jon’s behavior with Arya. He said nothing of the sort because he didn’t have to protect Sansa with lies when talking to Arya. This is Jon terrified of saying the wrong thing. This is “I’m loyal to my beloved Joffrey” Jon. And, yes, it’s bad writing. It is. They’re straining to keep up the ruse up until the last minute. They don’t want us to think that Jon is walking into the throne room determined to kill Dany. Even though Jon looked ready to assassinate her or at least betray her in some way earlier in the episode–or perhaps because he did–they now need to make us doubt that he’d ever go against her. And they needed to get in the line, “She doesn’t get to choose,” so that Dany’s line later, “They don’t get to choose,” makes it clear why Jon finally takes the plunge.

Sansa was always supposed to be the final trigger. But instead of making that explicit throughout the season (most likely because then it wouldn’t be as surprising), they did this.

When Jon stalks toward the throne room, I do think he’s already more or less made up his mind. He probably made it up earlier that day. But I also think he struggles with the decision because he thinks that, if he does it, he won’t make it out alive. He’ll never see his family again. He might even start a war between the Unsullied/Dothraki and the Northmen and KotV waiting outside the city gates. He knows it’s a dishonorable act. He knows Ned Stark would’ve found another way. 

Jon’s behavior once in the throne room is almost like the different stages of grief: denial, anger, bargaining, depression, acceptance. (And, again, I don’t think it’s because he loves her; it’s because of what he has to do and what it makes him.) Previously, even though he’s probably always known deep down that one day it would come to this, he’s been in denial. He’s done his very best to take the easy way out, to not confront, to hope he can keep mollifying her, but now he walks in angry.

While she’s gushing about the Iron Throne as if she didn’t just slaughtered a few hundred thousand people or so, Jon confronts her for the first time since… 7.04? Possibly 7.05 when he questioned her using Drogon on the battlefield. And I don’t think Jon would’ve done that if he believed Dany would leave that room alive. It’s much too dangerous. He’s avoided confronting her thus far for a reason.

And, remember, he just defended this act of hers to Tyrion. But now they’re letting us see how Jon really feels.

J: “I saw them executing Lannister prisoners in the street. They said they were acting on your orders.”

D: “It was necessary.”

J: “Necessary? Have you been down there? Have you seen? Children, little children, burned!”

D: “I tried to make peace with Cersei. She used their innocence as a weapon against me. She thought it would cripple me.”

A terrifying thing to say. It should’ve stayed Dany’s hand. And Jon knows it’s useless to argue, so he moves on and it leads to bargaining.

J: “And Tyrion?”

D: “He conspired behind my back with my enemies. How have you treated people who’ve done the same to you, even when it broke your heart?”

J: “Forgive him.”

D: “I can’t.”

J: “You can. You can forgive all of them, make them see they made a mistake. Make them understand. Please, Dany.”

What I think Jon is pleading for here isn’t that Dany forgives everyone. I think Jon’s desperately pleading for her to give him a reason to not go through with what he came to the throne room to do. He doesn’t want to kill her. He doesn’t. And especially not this way. It’s so easy for us to sit at home and judge and say KILL HER KILL HER. I sure as hell have said it. But would we be able to do it? In self-defense, maybe, but just walk up to her and stab her in the heart? I’m not sure I could’ve done it.

Yes, Jon has killed people before but only men. Women he’s avoided killing. Even when he banished Melisandre, he said that if she were to return to the North, he’d have her hanged as a murdered. Have her hanged = he wouldn’t do it himself. He couldn’t kill Ygritte. And this is complicated too. Dany is his blood. She is his family, in a way. And so the pleading goes on until we land here:

D: “It’s not easy to see something that’s never been before: a good world.”

J: “How do you know? How do you know it’ll be good?”

D: “Because I know what is good. And so do you.”

J: “I don’t.”

“I don’t,” he says because he’s thinking of what he has to do. He doesn’t know whether killing Dany in cold blood, in this moment where she’s happy and not putting anyone in immediate danger or hurting anyone, would be a good act. It might be necessary. Tyrion certainly seems to think so. But, again, isn’t that the excuse Dany uses? What would Ned Stark do? Would he find a better solution? A good solution. A fair and just (albeit riskier) solution. He would have, wouldn’t he?

Jon’s crying and lost. The depression stage. Where he should’ve received comfort, but instead Dany as always tries manipulating him into agreeing with her. She’s touching him–a hand on his chest, a hand on his shoulder–while he stands there passive. Struggling. Wrapping his head around what to do. On how to justify it to himself. He needs a trigger. And she gives him one – “They don’t get to choose.” – and you see the moment he realizes that he has to do it. 

There is no reasoning with her. He can’t control her with soft manipulation anymore. Burning down King’s Landing didn’t horrify her; it encouraged her. Every time she doles out her own brand of justice, it makes her more sure she’s right and good. Just like Tyrion said.

I think Jon knows now–that he accepts now–what he has to do. He’s not Ned Stark’s son. He’s not honorable. But he is the shield that guards the realms of men. And he is the man who’d kill to protect his family. 

Drogon is close by. They had a staring match before Jon entered the throne room. Jon has ridden Rhaegal. He knows about the bond, how a dragon can follow its rider’s unspoken commands. The moment Dany suspects something’s wrong, Drogon will act. She can’t suspect anything’s wrong.

So Jon lets her move in close. He lets her take his hand and put it on her cheek. When she asks him to break the wheel with her–basically a proposal–he gives her the only words he can. Not a yes. Not “I love you” because he doesn’t. He can’t tell her that; she’d know he’s lying and then the opportunity’s gone. She’s not love. She’s duty. He’s pledged himself to her. So he says: “You are my queen. Now and always.” An answer that pleases her. An answer she takes as a yes.

She moves in for the kiss. He stands completely still and lets it happen. And right before her lips touch his, his hand moves for the dagger.

I don’t like these writing choices, to be clear. They’re awful. It’s obvious that D&D wanted us to keep guessing up until Jon’s hand moved to his dagger. I’d read the leaks so I knew, but imagine if you hadn’t. I watched a reaction video the other day and people had a strong, negative reaction when they thought Jon said yes to Dany’s proposal–and then they cheered when he stabbed her. A room full of people who previously had cheered Dany on when she burned the Lannister army now cheered when Jon murdered her. This is what D&D wanted and so Jon’s characterization had to suffer. They decided to write a scene where he had to murder her while kissing her and it’s gross as hell. But this was the best way they knew how to shock us.

They also needed to show us that Jon is the opposite of Dany. They’ve been foils the whole series and with Tyrion’s comments earlier and Jon’s hesitation now, they’re making it clear once and for all: Dany would’ve done it. If she believed Jon was an evil man, she would’ve murdered him without hesitation and without regret. She kills and kills and kills and never questions the decision. It’s righteous. It’s just. It’s necessary.

So Jon has to question it. Jon’s instinct has to be to find a way out of it. To find a more peaceful solution, like his real father Ned Stark would’ve done. Because Jon isn’t fire and blood. He’s not Dany or Aerys.

And he has to be torn up about it too. He has to stare at her in shock, he has to cry, he has to ask Tyrion much later whether what they did was the right thing to do. He can’t be like Littlefinger who happily flings Lysa out the Moon Door after telling her the truth about his feelings. Jon’s our hero not a villain.

And yet Jon killed a woman. A woman he was related to, who loved him, who wanted him by her side, who believed he loved her back when he only ever used her, who lost so much because he used her, who chose fear because he couldn’t love her…   (No, I don’t think either is Jon’s fault, but I’m not so sure he would agree with me.)

So by murdering her this way, not in the heat of battle, not to stop her from actively hurting someone, not even by executing her after a fair trial, but as a precautionary measure, what does that make him?

A hero or a monster?

It’s an excellent question. Something that warrants a lot of discussion about ethics and morals. Something that could’ve made this episode very interesting had D&D actually had the guts to explore it. If they had let Jon speak openly with someone and confess that he didn’t love Dany, open up about his feelings and thoughts, this could’ve changed the whole season.

But instead they chose the very bloody version of will they/won’t they. They wanted us to be unsure of whether Jon would give in to the love they’ve tried to sell us (but Jon doesn’t actually feel) and rule by her side, or whether he would go against his own moral code and murder a woman. And now that I’ve seen the whole season, I can’t help but think that’s the main reason why Jnerys even existed in the first place. To make this murder into a really gross and horrible twist.

I know everyone and their gerbil tell us Jon loves Dany, that she’s the love of his life, that they’re star-crossed lovers and what have you. But I never saw him fall in love. I never saw him be happy with her (while I saw him being happy with everyone else). I only saw fear and annoyance and anger and obedience and playing a role. The cast telling me Jon loved her is not enough to change that. Tyrion thinking Jon loved Dany is not enough to change that. Jon crying over her dead body is not enough to change that. Isolated, that scene could’ve looked as if he loved her, but looking at this whole episode…? Looking at all of s8 and s7? It just does not make sense to me. 

I don’t know whether they filmed different versions of the assassination scene. I don’t know whether they retconned it late in the process and asked for reshoots and did the best they could with the editing. I don’t know whether they always wanted to keep it ambiguous. I don’t even know whether they went for starcrossed lovers and just failed epically. All of them. Except Ramin Djawadi lmao. All I know is that I never saw Jon loving Dany and so I can’t believe it.

So this is my take. This is how I make sense of Jon’s characterization, which seemingly only ever existed because of a twist. As infuriating as that is.

Thanks for the ask!

trail.content_raw:
2/3 What gets Jon fired up? When Tyrion says Dany’s nature is fire and blood. This upsets Jon NOT because he believes in Dany, but because he feels it’s an attack on him. His defends her because if what Tyrion says is true, then what if he is the same. So he scrambles to make an excuse for her rage. Maybe he’s recalling how he let his rage take over in the past, with Ramsay, LF. If he had a dragon, would he have done the same? Immediately, Tyrion asks if he’d have done the same and Jon falters.

3/3 The show seemed desperate to incorporate “love is death of duty” here, but it doesn’t apply. Jon isn’t in love with Dany. Tyrion talks realm, Jon’s own life being in danger, none of which stir him to action. Tyrion then asks about Sansa, similar to Varys with Ned in S1 (“love is death of duty” doesn’t apply here either), which gives Jon pause. He chooses Sansa over Dany. Sansa = familial/romantic love, not duty. Like Ned, this was about love (Sansa) vs honor (killing his kin and Queen).

You’ve hit the nail on the head, anon.

When I watched this episode, I was so disappointed that the leaks were true that I just watched on in exasperation and detachment. And even though I picked up on a few things (like the repeated mention of Sansa affecting Jon, and Jon’s head shake at the claim he loves Dany), I still read the scene like most people did: Jon defended Dany which felt like a complete retcon from what happened in the previous episode and also felt very out of character for Jon.

I was so sick of the show that I didn’t really want to dig deeper, but yesterday I rewatched a few scenes and you’re right. Jon’s defending himself.

But let’s rewind. I’d like to go through the scenes before we reach the makeshift cell scene, because those scenes should inform how we read Jon’s interactions with Tyrion and Dany later. Jon keeps showing us that he doesn’t agree with her actions, after all.

(Oh, and this will be long, but it has visual aids. Yay?)

[[MORE]]

In 8.05 Jon sort of goes against order. Granted, Dany never commanded him to keep fighting, but she keeps fighting and Grey Worm keeps fighting. If Jon really truly followed Dany, he would keep fighting too. But his morals stop him. He sheathes his sword and tries getting everyone out of the city.

Then 8.06 starts. We follow Tyrion (with Jon and Davos close behind) walking back into King’s Landing on a street littered with corpses and ashes and crumbled buildings. They stop at the charred remains of the mother and child Arya tried to help. The little girl still holding her toy horse. Tyrion tells Jon he’ll find him later to which Jon replies, “It’s not safe. Let me send some men with you.”

Why isn’t it safe? We don’t know whether Tyrion has told Jon about Jaime, but it’s most likely common knowledge by now and Tyrion did include Davos in his betrayal. It was from Davos Tyrion asked the favor to help in smuggling Cersei and Jaime to Pentos. We don’t need to see Davos and Tyrion telling Jon. It’s implied that he knows. And when Tyrion tells Jon, “I’m going alone,” and Jon follows him with his eyes as Tyrion leaves, the look on Jon’s face also implies he knows that Tyrion will try to find out whether his family made it out. Jon’s not afraid that a King’s Landing survivor will attack Tyrion; Jon is afraid of what Dany will do if she gets her hands on Tyrion. And Jon sending men with Tyrion to protect him is also defying Dany.

After this, Jon interrupts Grey Worm while the latter sentences prisoners of war to die in the name of his queen. Both Jon and Davos argue for the prisoners to remain alive; however, GW has different orders.

GW: “I obey my queen’s commands, not yours.”
Jon: “And what are the queen’s commands?”
GW: “Kill all who follow Cersei Lannister.”

Jon physically stops Grey Worm from following these orders and once more Jon defies Dany. Everyone around them draws their weapons. Jon and Grey Worm enter a staring match, and it’s Davos who brings Jon back by telling him they need to speak to the queen. And yet it still takes Jon a long moment to step back. He glances at the prisoners, deliberating, looks back at GW. He doesn’t want to let GW kill them, but he also knows that if he and his men engage in a battle against the Unsullied, Jon puts even more people at risk. Especially his family, who’ll suffer if Dany learns that Jon fought her men. So he makes his decision and walks away.

As he walks through the square, surrounded by Dothraki, low and dark music drones ominously in the background. Jon looks hard. He glares up at the stairs where the Targaryen banner is hung. Drogon and his rider fly above. 

Jon stares up at them with an expression that shows us his real feelings for Dany–and they sure as hell aren’t warm. Nor is he heartbroken because he was wrong about the ~love of his life~. The tension in his mouth doesn’t quite reach Jon Snow Growl status, but it’s not far from it.

I think Jon knew that he was heading into a situation that would end with bloodshed in some way or another and he was preparing himself mentally. Grey Worm has kept an eye on Jon’s treasonous behavior. He will report to his queen first chance he gets–and Jon and Dany have a strained relationship as it is. But Jon can’t run away either. If he does, Dany will fly after him or even attack his home and his family. All he can do is move forward and try working out a plan.

Dany holds her terrifying speech and we get a reaction shot of Jon watching her with a dark look in his eyes. It’s in these moments–when she can’t see his face–we’re allowed to see Jon’s true feelings. There’s no love in his eyes. No heartbreak. Not until she mentions Winterfell and we see Jon realizing what this means.

This is where Jon’s emotions peek through. His love and worry for his family. No, he doesn’t speak Valyrian but he’s not stupid. He knows what this means.

Tyrion is accused of treason in front of Jon (another reminder of what happens to those who favor family over Dany), throws away his Hand pin, and, as he’s led away, exchanges a pointed look with Jon.

Then Jon and Dany exchange a look. A long look. One that, perhaps, was supposed to make us worried she’d have Jon escorted off to a cell too. But she only stares at him with contempt before leaving (which makes her quick change in mood later rather odd but, well, apparently EC disagrees). As she walks away, Jon does not follow the ~love of his life~ with his eyes. Not until she and the Unsullied have safely passed him does he turn around and glare at her.

He loathes her. I think even looking at her leaves him with a bad taste in his mouth. There’s nothing about his behavior that suggests to me that this is a guy who just realized the woman of his dreams was a monster. He knew. Perhaps not that she was quite this much of a monster. But he knew.

After Arya pops up out of nowhere, they have a conversation about Dany. Arya calls Dany Jon’s queen (as she often does) and Jon replies with, “She’s everyone’s queen now.” His voice is gravelly and the way he delivers it, it’s clear he doesn’t think that’s a good thing. It’s clear he and Arya stand on one side, and Dany on the other. He could just as well have said, “Welcome to hell.” That’s the kind of delivery he gives.

What follows next has annoyed me and others, because Arya says two things to Jon that Tyrion repeats in the makeshift cell scene. It annoyed me and others because why repeat it? What’s the point?

Contrast.

Jon reacts one way to Arya and a whole different way to Tyrion. It’s not inconsistency but a chance for us to compare the real Jon (with Arya) and political!Jon/sacrifical!jon (with Tyrion). It’s not well-written, to be clear, but I do believe this is why they did it. Their clumsy way of giving clues.

When Arya points out Sansa won’t ever bend to Dany, Jon doesn’t protest. He knows it’s true. He doesn’t say that Sansa doesn’t get to choose. He doesn’t say anything at all. He knows it’s true and he knows what it means. He’s tried avoiding confrontation with Dany because she’s a dangerous woman to confront, but it’s now become unavoidable. She mentioned Winterfell in her speech. She hates Sansa. She knows Sansa spread her secret. It’s only a matter of time.

I’m still not entirely sure what Jon’s plan was here, but when he tells Arya to wait for him outside the city gates, I think he was a man on a mission already. Perhaps he was considering killing Drogon (which would leave Dany just another regular foe. Her armies against his). Perhaps he would make things up as he went along.

Perhaps he even realizes that he needs to kill Dany. Perhaps he’s prepared to do it.

But before he can leave, Arya stops him and points out another thing, “Jon. She knows who you are. Who you really are. You’ll always be a threat to her.“

Jon doesn’t comment on this either. He doesn’t say it’s Dany’s right to kill him. He doesn’t defend Dany. He only sighs. This is the real Jon. Jon does not believe that Dany would be in the right. Not at all.

They keep showing us how Jon feels about her. When Dany can’t see him, Jon shows his true feelings. Anger, fear, contempt, disapproval. They show us repeatedly in this episode that Jon would never defend Dany’s actions. Which leads us to the scene where Jon defends Dany’s actions. :)

The Jon who walks into Tyrion’s cell isn’t in “let’s defend Dany!” mode. When Tyrion says he betrayed his queen, Jon tells him he didn’t because contrary to what the characters and the cast and the crew try telling us constantly, Jon isn’t so far up Dany’s ass that he can’t tell right from wrong anymore. Tyrion released his brother. Jon would’ve done the same. 

“And I’d do it again,” Tyrion says, “now that I’ve seen what I’ve seen. I chose my fate. The people of King’s Landing did not.”

“I can’t justify what happened,” Jon says. “I won’t try.”

Looking at Jon’s expression he’s heartbroken over what happened in King’s Landing. He’s most likely still struggling to fully process it and also wondering how much of it is his fault. “Let it be fear,” she said because he couldn’t love her and she sure as hell showed them fear. It’s in no way Jon’s fault, but what person wouldn’t blame themselves on at least some level?

Then Tyrion points out the war is far from over:

T: “She liberated the people of Slaver’s Bay. She liberated the people of King’s Landing. And she’ll go on liberating until the people of the world are free and she rules them all.”

J: “And you’ve been by her side, counseling her. Until today.”

T: ″Until today.”

Jon doesn’t hide is disapproval at Tyrion having been Dany’s Hand. 

Look at the guy. Jon is judging Tyrion. Please look at this gif and tell me that Jon–the real Jon (because this is the real Jon, for once)–would actually defend Dany. There’s even a hint of an incredulous amusement, as if he thinks Tyrion is a god damn hypocrite and he can’t believe the words coming out of the guy’s mouth.

Jon seems to think, “If you knew all along what she is, then why the hell did you help her in invading Westeros? Why did you snitch on Varys when Varys was trying to stop her?” And it’s easy for Jon to judge. He got involved with Dany because death was coming and he believed he needed her dragons and her armies to stop it. He did what he had to to save everyone he loves and, you know, the world. And he’s stayed by Dany’s side because he needed to protect his family from her. What was Tyrion’s excuse?

Then comes the complete switch in Jon’s attitude. The switch that you, anon, brought up: Tyrion makes this about House words. He makes it about blood.

T: “Our queen’s nature is fire and blood–”

J: “You think our house words are stamped on our bodies when we’re born and that’s who we are? Then I’d be fire and blood too.“

“Then I’d be fire and blood too.”

Finally, Jon’s identity crisis is addressed: he’s triggered by the suggestion that he and Dany could be the same.

Unfortunately, this is not just way too damn late. It’s also badly written because it’s so very contrived.

I think this scene mostly exists for two reasons: they needed someone to explain to the audience why assassinating Dany was justified, to point out that this is her pattern, and make sure we all knew that she needed to be stopped. Which is hamfisted and insulting to the audience’s intelligence. But they also wanted to actually insult their audience by pointing out that those of us who’ve cheered Dany on were part of the problem. We’ve accepted her horrible deeds without questioning. We’ve cheered her on and she’s grown stronger and stronger as an icon until she became the face of this show. They’re basically slapping their audience in the face for drinking the koolaid they gave us.

But they’re also asking a rather interesting question that, in better hands, could’ve made this scene very compelling: if it were you, if you were the one with almost unlimited power, would you be any better?

If you could round up really bad criminals and burn them alive without repercussions, would you do it? Would you do it even if you weren’t 100% sure everyone was guilty?
